title: Tom Cruise Really Did Get a US Aircraft Carrier for This Mission
content:
For fans of Tom Cruise’s Mission: Impossible series, the Pentagon can answer the incredulous question at the climax of its latest trailer: “You gave him an aircraft carrier?”
Yes, the US Navy and Air Force Special Operations decided to accept the mission: help Cruise’s secret agent Ethan Hunt save the world. Or, at least make a movie about it.
For Paramount Global’s The Final Reckoning, released Friday in the US, Cruise and the crew spent three days in the Adriatic Sea filming aboard the USS George H.W. Bush, a nuclear powered Nimitz-class carrier commissioned in 2009. 
It’s the latest cinematic incarnation of Cruise’s career-long affinity for the US military and its aircraft (as well as doing his own stunts). It’s also an example of the Pentagon’s willingness to showcase its hardware and martial might through a classic piece of American soft power, the Hollywood blockbuster. (Source: Bloomberg)

content: Car dealership groups in two provinces have gone out of business since last month in China, both of them BYD Co. retailers, evidence of the tough competition in the nation’s auto market and proof that not even selling the country’s No. 1 brand can shield businesses from financial difficulties.

title: China’s Meituan, Xiaomi See Long-Term Expansion Efforts in Spotlight
content: Meituan and Xiaomi Corp.’s long-term ambitions and investment plans will dominate next week’s earnings releases, continuing to shape sentiment for China’s tech sector.

title: OnlyFans in Talks for Sale at $8 Billion Valuation, Reuters Says
content: A Los Angeles investment firm is in discussions to buy out OnlyFans Ltd. in a deal that values the site at $8 billion, Reuters reported.

title: Live Action ‘Elden Ring’ Film in Works, Directed by Alex Garland
content: A24 Films and Bandai Namco Entertainment Inc. will work with Ex Machina director Alex Garland on a live-action film based on the fantasy role-playing game Elden Ring.

title: YouTube Poaches Disney Official, Triggering Lawsuit Against Video Service
content: Disney responds with a complaint in California court claiming breach of contract

title: Workday Gives Lackluster Growth Outlook Despite New AI Tools
content: Workday Inc. projected subscription revenue in the current quarter in line with Wall Street estimates, disappointing investors looking for the software company to get a boost from new artificial intelligence features for its products.

title: OpenAI's UAE Data Center, AT&T-Lumen Consumer Fiber Deal | Bloomberg Technology
content: Bloomberg’s Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow talk to OpenAI’s Global Policy President Chris Lehane about the company’s plans to build more international data centers. Plus, Kraken Co-CEO Arjun Sethi discusses why the crypto exchange has partnered with Backed to let customers outside the US trade Apple, Nvidia, and Tesla shares around the clock. And AT&T CEO John Stankey explains why the telecom giant is buying Lumen’s consumer fiber operations. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: How Britain’s Stats Geeks Lost Track of the Economy
content: Just before midday on May 9, employees of the Office for National Statistics were summoned to an urgent call.

title: Trump Forces Switzerland to Question Its Love for Farmers
content: Switzerland’s bid for a US trade deal risks sparking a showdown with one political force at least as feisty as President Donald Trump: its own farmers.

title: Japan Signals Intent to Reach US Tariff Deal by G-7 in June
content: Japan’s chief trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa indicated his aim to resolve tariff talks in time for a June meeting between US President Donald Trump and Japan’s Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba following Trump’s surprise pivot to allow a partnership between two of the countries’ steelmakers.

title: Meloni Wins Hope of Moody’s Italy Upgrade From Brink of Junk
content: Italy’s credit score is skewed toward a potential upgrade at Moody’s Ratings, which has just joined rivals in rewarding Premier Giorgia Meloni’s push for fiscal restraint.

title: Trump Threatens EU, Smartphones as Tariff Rhetoric Escalates
content: President Donald Trump dug in on his threat to impose a 50% tariff on the European Union and said a potential 25% charge on smartphones would apply to all foreign-made devices, in the latest escalation of a trade war that is rattling markets and confusing businesses.

title: Paraguay Holds Key Rate at 6% Amid Steady Inflation Expectations
content: Paraguay’s central bank kept its benchmark interest rate steady at 6%, citing stable long-term inflation expectations congruent with its target.

title: Chile Finance Chief Wants to Unlock Billions in New Investments
content: Chile’s government is readying legislation to unlock billions of dollars of investments by speeding up the approval process, following years of complaints over excessive red tape, Finance Minister Mario Marcel said.

title: Bessent Says Trump Paused Sovereign Wealth Fund to Focus on Debt
content: US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the Trump administration paused plans to create a sovereign wealth fund as the president prioritizes paying down the national debt.

title: Bessent Sees Easing Capital Rule on Treasuries This Summer
content: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said that US regulators this summer may ease a rule that’s served as a constraint on banks’ trading in the $29 trillion Treasuries market.

title: Ghana Holds Key Rate as Cedi Rally Seen Taming Inflation
content: Ghana’s central bank kept its key interest rate on hold to maintain downward pressure on inflation, which is expected to get a boost from the West African nation’s world-beating currency.

title: Bessent Sees ‘Several Large’ Trade Deals in Next Few Weeks
content: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said there could be “several large” trade deals announced in the next couple of weeks, adding that he expects Trump administration officials will meet with their Chinese counterparts again in-person to negotiate those tariffs.

title: European Officials Urge ‘Calm’ Facing Trump 50% Tariff Threat
content: European officials sought to portray a unified calm after US President Donald Trump threatened to impose a 50% tariff on the bloc’s imports, a potential escalation that sent stocks tumbling on both sides of the Atlantic on concerns a trade war will disrupt the world’s largest commercial and investment relationship.

title: Euro-Zone’s Top Economies May Now Have Inflation at or Under 2%
content: Inflation in all of the euro zone’s four biggest economies is at or below the European Central Bank’s 2% target, according to economists.

title: Tracking Every Trump Tariff and Its Economic Effect
content: For the full experience visit: Tracking Every Trump Tariff and Its Economic Effect

title: US New-Home Sales Jump to Highest Since 2022 as Prices Fall
content: US new-home sales rose unexpectedly in April to the highest level since February 2022, likely helped by builder incentives aimed at alleviating affordability challenges.

title: Fed Must Contain Long-Term Inflation Expectations, Musalem Says
content: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis President Alberto Musalem said officials are focused on keeping long-run inflation expectations stable as businesses and consumers anticipate prices to rise in the near term.

title: Economists Say Canada Recession Has Already Begun as Trade War Rages On
content: Canada’s economy is likely in the early stages of a recession, according to forecasters, as unemployment rises and exports fall because of a trade war with the US.

title: RBI to Make a Record Transfer of $32 Billion to Government
content: India’s central bank will give a record dividend to the government, shoring up finances to bolster growth in Asia’s third largest economy.

title: US Inflation, Recession Forecasts Ease on Trade Truce With China
content: Latest Bloomberg survey still suggests economy is shifting into a lower gear

title: Ghana’s Debt Burden Falls to IMF Threshold Ahead of 2028 Target
content: Ghana’s debt burden fell to a threshold required by the International Monetary Fund’s $3 billion program three years ahead of schedule, as the the new government curbed borrowing.

title: European Bonds Rally as Trump Tariff Threat Fuels Rate-Cut Bets
content: European bonds rallied after US President Donald Trump threatened to apply levies of 50% on the region starting June 1, fueling bets policymakers will have to lower interest rates further to support the economy.

title: ECB’s Lane Says US Price Jump Wouldn’t Necessarily Reach Europe
content: Faster US inflation triggered by President Donald Trump’s tariffs wouldn’t necessarily spill over into the euro zone, according to European Central Bank Chief Economist Philip Lane.

title: ECB’s Kazimir to Receive Verdict in Bribery Case Next Week
content: The bribery trial of European Central Bank Governing Council member Peter Kazimir is expected to deliver a verdict next week.

title: EU Agrees to Reinstate Trade Quotas on Ukraine as War Drags on
content: The European Union has agreed to reinstate quotas on imports of several agricultural goods from Ukraine, adding to the challenges faced by its war-hit economy.

title: Sickly Animals Remind the World of Fragile Food Trade
content: Lethargic chickens with swollen heads or cattle with maggots burrowing into their flesh — these are effects of diseases that have been disrupting global trade.

title: The $3 Trillion in Capital Needed to Bring Back US Factory Jobs
content: I’m Mark Niquette, a US economy reporter in Columbus, Ohio. Today we’re looking at bringing back manufacturing jobs to the US. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.

title: Euro-Zone Wage Growth Sinks, Supporting Further ECB Easing
content: A key measure of euro-area pay growth plunged, supporting the European Central Bank’s claim that inflation will soon hit the 2% target and backing calls to lower interest rates further.

title: US Aid Retreat Opens Door for Bigger Islamic Development Bank Role in Africa
content: The Islamic world’s premier lending institution said it’s prepared to step up support for some of its neediest members, as the US and others slash aid programs for Africa and beyond.

title: Bulgaria Is on Track to Win EU Approval to Join the Euro Next Year
content: Bulgaria is close to clearing a major hurdle toward euro adoption, putting the Black Sea nation on course to join the currency area next year.

title: Zambia Halts Rate Hikes as Corn Boom Seen Cooling Inflation
content: Zambia’s central bank held its key interest rate as it expects the disinflation process to continue.

title: Andrew Left’s Lawyer Says Case Doesn’t Fit Trump Priorities
content: Short seller Andrew Left is making a new push to sway the US Justice Department to drop fraud charges filed against him last year, hiring a former federal prosecutor to make fresh arguments directly to the Trump administration.

title: Cenovus Executive Downplays Chance of MEG Bid Amid Organic Growth Push
content: A Cenovus Energy Inc. executive downplayed the chance the oil sands producer would offer to buy MEG Energy Corp., saying the company is more focused on expanding existing assets than making acquisitions.

title: Cobalto del Congo: el nuevo campo de batalla en la lucha entre China y EE.UU.
content: En medio de una guerra comercial global, el Congo intenta cortejar a la Casa Blanca de Trump sin arriesgar inversiones cruciales de Pekín.

title: Carney’s Energy Chief Pushes Oil Sands to Build Carbon-Capture Systems
content: Canada’s new energy minister said it’s critical to build carbon-capture systems for the oil sands and identified crude and natural gas exports as a major priority for Prime Minister Mark Carney’s government.

title: McDonald’s to Close Beverage-Focused Concept Stores, Test New Drinks
content: McDonald’s Corp. plans to close standalone CosMc’s stores, winding down its experiment with the beverage-focused concept.

title: Harvard Wins Temporary Block of Trump’s Foreign Student Ban
content: Harvard University won a temporary court order blocking the Trump administration from enforcing a ban on international students at the school, giving it a win in a high-stakes legal fight with broad implications for higher education in the US.

title: Rio Tinto Board Looks for a New CEO Who Knows Mining Better
content: When Jakob Stausholm took the top job at Rio Tinto Group, his task was to repair the reputation of a company that had just blasted through a 46,000-year-old sacred Aboriginal site and bungled its response. Now the world’s second-largest miner has decided it needs a boss that can lead it into the future.

title: Lauder, L’Oreal Suffer as China Duty-Free Spend Falls
content: Unable to travel overseas during the Covid-19 pandemic, Chinese consumers sparked a shopping boom in the southernmost province of Hainan, lured by the tropical island’s plethora of duty-free shopping malls.

title: What Happens When an Italian Racing Team Meets the Indy 500
content: Prema sets sights on making history this weekend after the Italian team took pole position.

title: Volvo Car CEO Rejects Worries Over R&D Shifting to China
content: Upcoming job cuts at Volvo Car AB are not a sign that the carmaker’s Chinese owner is taking more control over product development, Chief Executive Officer Hakan Samuelsson said.

title: Italy Plans to Stick With Its Tough Terms on UniCredit’s BPM Bid
content: Italy is set to keep the strict conditions it imposed on UniCredit SpA to take over rival lender Banco BPM SpA, even if the bidder starts a legal battle to ease those terms.

title: Travel Anxiety Swells as Airports Face Busiest Memorial Day Ever
content: Flyers heading out for the Memorial Day holiday in the US are bracing for stress as record numbers of travelers place fresh strain on an outmoded and undermanned air traffic system.

title: Visa, Mastercard Fees Hit by New Round of EU Antitrust Scrutiny
content: Visa Inc. and Mastercard Inc. fees are under fresh scrutiny from European Union antitrust enforcers, less than a decade after a series of probes ended with hefty fines and an agreement to cut some of their controversial levies.

title: Musk Backer to Join New Ownership at Reading Football Club
content: Aliya Capital Partners, a Miami-based investment firm, is joining the ownership group that bought out 154-year-old Reading Football Club from Chinese businessman Dai Yongge.

title: Nigerian Manufacturers ‘Harassed’ Over FX Contracts, Lobby Says
content: Nigerian manufacturers say they’re being “harassed” by lenders over outstanding forward foreign exchange contracts with the central bank.

title: UniCredit Escalates BPM Fight With Italy by Going to Court
content: UniCredit SpA is escalating the standoff with the Italian government over its bid for rival Banco BPM SpA as the firm plans to take the matter to court.

title: Hensoldt Said to Weigh Sale of South African Optronics Unit
content: German radar maker Hensoldt AG is exploring options for its South African optronics business, including a potential sale, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: EU Set to Delay Implementation of Bank Trading Rule
content: The European Commission is set to recommend a fresh delay to the adoption of new trading book rules that govern the trading activities of banks, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: US Firms Face Biggest Hit on Trump Tariffs, HSBC Survey Says
content: US businesses are the most worried about the impact of President Donald Trump’s shifting tariff policies on their revenues, with more than half projecting a hit of at least 25% to their revenue, according to a survey by HSBC Holdings Plc.

title: US Approves GSK Lung Disease Drug, Fueling Sanofi Rivalry
content: GSK Plc won US approval for its drug to treat a deadly lung disease, ramping up competition with rival Sanofi.

title: Wall Street, Aussie Banks Stuck With DAZN’s Foxtel M&A Loan
content: Some of Wall Street and Australia’s largest banks are stuck holding part of an A$1.8 billion ($1.2 billion) loan backing DAZN Group Ltd’s takeover of Rupert Murdoch’s Australian pay-television provider Foxtel Management Pty., according to people familiar with the matter.

title: China’s Retreat From US Corn Makes It Cheaper for Rest of Asia
content: China’s shift away from US corn is benefiting other Asian buyers as cheaper American supply flows into the broader market, shaking up competition for the grain used in animal feed and biofuels.

title: Siam Cement Mulls Reopening $5.4 Billion Plant as Prices Rebound
content: Siam Cement Pcl is looking to resume operations at its $5.4 billion petrochemicals complex in Vietnam, amid signs prices depressed by a period of oversupply have hit the bottom.

title: ISS Recommends Akio Toyoda’s Reappointment After Prior Concerns Over Governance
content: A firm that advises large investors backed the reappointment of Chairman Akio Toyoda to Toyota Motor Corp.’s board, reversing its position from a year ago.

title: Pemex Eyes Job Cuts to Save $540 Million Via Restructuring
content: Mexico’s state oil company Petroleos Mexicanos is discussing plans to slash over 3,000 jobs in a proposed corporate restructuring that is expected to save the company millions as the indebted driller and refiner tries to shore up its finances and boost production.

title: Brookfield Eyes More Singapore Deals From REITs Under Pressure
content: Brookfield Asset Management sees the potential for more property acquisitions from real estate investment trusts in Singapore after its first deal in the city-state.

title: RFK Jr. Report Blames Diet, Overmedication for Chronic Diseases
content: The Trump administration issued a report blaming the rise in chronic diseases in the US on unhealthy food ingredients, chemicals, overreliance on medication and corporate spending. But it stopped short of attacking growers and manufacturers as much as they feared.

title: China’s Lithium City Is a Front Line of the Battery Trade War
content: Beijing wants a high-tech economy built on domestic supply, even if it comes at a cost.

title: Ethereum’s ‘Trillion-Dollar Security’ Quest to Regain Its Edge
content: Sidhartha Shukla takes a look at the “trillion-dollar security” plan for Ethereum.

title: Senate Votes to Block California Ban on Gasoline-Fueled Cars
content: The US Senate voted to block a California program banning gasoline-powered cars and other vehicles by 2035, sending the measure to President Donald Trump’s desk for his signature.

title: House Republican bill boosts maximum child tax credit to $2,500
content: The House Republican multi-trillion-dollar tax package includes a bigger child tax credit. If enacted, here's who could benefit from the changes.

title: The U.S. credit downgrade is not the problem. Our reckless spending is
content: Habitual deficit financing — the very disease Alexander Hamilton warned against — has become business as usual.

title: Google Wallet users in the US get another upgrade this week
content: The digital wallet now supports over 5,000 banks and credit unions, making it the most popular mobile payment service.

title: Can buy now, pay later debt be sold to debt collectors?
content: Missed a few BNPL payments? You could face more than late fees. Here's how to protect yourself and your credit.

title: How can credit counseling help with my credit card debt?
content: Before you sign up for credit counseling, it's important to understand what it can do to help you get rid of debt.

title: China cuts benchmark lending rates for the first time in 7 months in Beijing's growth push
content: The People's Bank of China trimmed the 1-year loan prime rate to 3.0% from 3.1%, and the 5-year LPR to 3.5% from 3.6%.

title: California bill calls for program to insure multifamily development loans
content: Sen. Dave Cortese has called on the state to use its credit to insure construction and permanent loans for multifamily developments, giving them access to more favorable interest terms

title: Mortgage rates cross back over 7% after U.S. credit downgrade
content: After several weeks of sitting stagnant, mortgage rates surged higher Monday following Moody’s decision to downgrade the U.S. credit rating.

title: Ray Dalio says the risk to U.S. Treasurys is even greater than what Moody’s is saying
content: Bridgewater Associates founder and billionaire Ray Dalio warned Monday that Moody’s downgrade of the U.S. sovereign credit rating understates the threat to U.S.

content: With interest rates high and the prospects of relief low, here are three considerations borrowers should make now.

title: SEC’s Anti-Fraud Public Service Campaign Warns Investors About Relationship Investment Scams
content: The SEC’s Office of Investor Education and Advocacy unveiled its anti-fraud public service campaign, which warns investors about the devastating impact relationship investment scams can have on their financial future.

content: April is Financial Literacy Month, and the SEC is encouraging investors to utilize the agency’s saving and investing resources on Investor.gov.

content: The SEC&#039;s Crypto Task Force will hold four more roundtables in its ongoing series discussing crypto asset regulation.

title: Filer Transition to New and Improved EDGAR Begins March 24
content: The Securities and Exchange Commission is providing extensive guidance and resources to assist filers with upcoming access and account management enhancements to the security of the agency’s Electronic Data Gathering, Analysis, and Retrieval (EDGAR)…

title: Fintech Funding Holds Strong As Airwallex Lands $300M
content: Business payments platform Airwallex has announced that it closed on $300 million at a $6.2 billion valuation. The financing includes $150 million in Series F funding and another $150 million for secondary share purchases.

title: Proofpoint To Buy Hornetsecurity For Around $1B
content: Cybersecurity company Proofpoint announced that it plans to acquire Hornetsecurity, a security provider specialized in Microsoft 365 software tools, in a deal reportedly valued at around $1 billion.

title: Venture Capital’s Second(ary) Chance
content: The lack of a healthy exit market is an existential problem for the venture capital industry, writes guest author Dan Gray, who sees the evolving strategy of secondary markets as one solution.

title: DFJ Growth Closes $1.2B Flagship Fund
content: Venture investor DFJ Growth announced it has raised $1.2 billion for a fifth flagship fund, its largest to date.

title: Tariffs And The Venture Value Chain: A Blip Or Long-Term Pain?
content: Guest author Rohit Yadav takes us on an exploration of the value chain — VC fundraising, startup fundraising and exits — to see how tariffs are driving both direct and indirect impacts.

title: The Longer IPOs Delay, The Less Likely Debuts Will Happen
content: Over the past couple weeks, as we’ve seen Klarna, StubHub and others delay scheduled pre-IPO roadshows, it appears markets are to blame. But how will delays affect a company's success when it finally makes its debut?

title: Crypto Startup Ripple Buys Hidden Road For $1.25B
content: Crypto payments firm Ripple is acquiring brokerage house Hidden Road for $1.25 billion in one of the biggest M&A deals ever in crypto.

title: Tariffs, Volatility And The Startup Exit Dilemma
content: Even seasoned startup investors today face what feels like a novel turn of events: a potential recession and increasing exit uncertainty due to government-induced volatility, writes guest author Don Butler of Thomvest Ventures.  For an ecosystem that has long awaited the return of robust exit volumes, the uncertainty in the markets sparked by tariffs couldn’t come at a worse time.

title: CoreWeave Closes Flat In First-Day Trading
content: Shares of CoreWeave closed flat at $40 on their first day of trading on the Nasdaq today. Shares had opened at $39 on Friday, a day when the Nasdaq sank 2.7%.

title: CoreWeave Shrinks IPO
content: Cloud computing startup CoreWeave is cutting the size of its IPO, looking for a valuation closer to $23 billion than the roughly $30 billion it had originally targeted.

title: Want To Sell Your Startup Quickly To A Strategic Buyer? Consider This From The Get-Go
content: Whether buying a startup or selling one, there are plenty of steps that need to be considered, writes guest author Murat Abdrakhmanov. In this commentary he provides recommendations to help both buyer and seller reach their strategic and financial goals.

title: Q1 Global Startup Funding Posts Strongest Quarter Since Q2 2022 With A Third Going To Massive OpenAI Deal
content: Overall, the first quarter of 2025 marked the strongest one for venture investment since Q2 2022. Funding was up 17% quarter over quarter from the $96 billion reached in Q4 2024.

title: A Deep Dive Into The Leading Investors In Unicorns Minted Since 2023
content: Since 2023, 259 new unicorns have joined The Crunchbase Unicorn Board, adding $605 billion in total value and altogether raising $130 billion, Crunchbase data shows. We take a look at who's leading new investments.

title: Looking Back 10 Years, Seed Investors Envisioned A Different Future Unfolding
content: Reviewing old seed funding data is a lot like going into the past to see what people thought the future would look like. Going back roughly 10 years ago, it seems OpenAI was the company every seed investor should have backed, but who knew how times would change for the intended nonprofit.

title: Global Venture Funding Slowed In April, Despite Strong AI Showing
content: Global venture funding totaled $23 billion in April 2025, flat year over year and down significantly month over month from $68 billion invested in March, Crunchbase data shows.

title: How To Leverage Your Pre-Seed Funding For Rapid And Successful Growth
content: After the pre-seed round is a time for a startup to plan for securing follow-on investments, says guest author Sergei Bogdanov, who shares early-stage funding advice to founders regarding what to do as well as what not to do.

title: Most-Active Startup Investors Spent More In Q1
content: The busiest venture backers upped their game in the recently ended first quarter. Among the 14 most-active post-seed investors, a majority backed more deals in Q1 2025 than they did a year ago.

title: Europe’s VC Funding Stayed Flat In Q1, Even As Healthcare Added A Third
content: Europe’s venture funding plateaued at $12.6 billion in Q1 2025 — flat quarter over quarter and year over year, Crunchbase data shows. Without the sort of outsized AI funding rounds seen in North America in the first quarter, the continent’s share of global funding also fell.

title: Latin America Startup Funding Fell Sequentially In Q1
content: Latin America startup investment declined sequentially in the first quarter of this year, driven by a drop in later-stage dealmaking. Even so, funding was above the depressed levels seen a year ago, and early-stage dealmaking showed signs of strength.

title: SignalFire Closes On $1B To Invest In Applied AI
content: Bay Area-based SignalFire, a data-driven venture firm, has raised $1 billion for its fifth and largest fund, which it will invest in applied AI companies.

title: North America Startup Investment Spiked In Q1 Due To OpenAI, But Seed And Early Stage Fell
content: Despite several big deals that buoyed the numbers, North America early- and seed-stage investment declined to multiquarter lows in Q1, and reported round counts fell across stages.

title: Q1 Global Startup Funding Posts Strongest Quarter Since Q2 2022 With A Third Going To Massive OpenAI Deal
content: Overall, the first quarter of 2025 marked the strongest one for venture investment since Q2 2022. Funding was up 17% quarter over quarter from the $96 billion reached in Q4 2024.

title: 7 Deadly Pitch Deck Sins, According To A VC
content: VC firms receive thousands of pitch decks a year and a typical investor will spend no more than two to three minutes assessing each one. In this guest commentary, investor Michael Tefula of Ada Ventures shares seven of the biggest mistakes that are more likely to land your pitch in the “no, thanks” rejection bin.
